required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Transcutaneous Tibial Nerve Stimulation for Urgency Urinary Incontinence
clinical_study.official_title: Transcutaneous Tibial Nerve Stimulation for Urgency Urinary Incontinence: A Sham-Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This is a single-center, double-blinded, randomized controlled trial evaluating the efficacy of TTNS versus a sham intervention. Both interventions will be performed by participants in their homes after standardized instruction. The primary outcome is a comparison of the mean change in OAB-q scores before and after treatment between the intervention and control groups. Changes in the number of urgency incontinence episodes and an estimation of cost effectiveness will additionally be measured. Intention to treat analysis will be performed.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: To evaluate the efficacy of a 12-week course of TTNS in reducing urgency urinary incontinence (UUI) symptom bother in the intervention versus sham group.

secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate the efficacy of a 12-week course of TTNS in reducing the frequency of UUI episodes in the intervention versus sham group.

other_outcome.description: To describe the cost effectiveness of a 12-week course of home-based TTNS therapy using an ICER calculated from the sum of direct medical and indirect non-medical costs relative to health-related quality of life, as measured by the European Quality of Life-5 Dimensions index.

intervention.description: TTNS is a non-invasive, surface electrode therapeutic stimulation technique available for home administration that has been proposed as a treatment for overactive bladder.
The sham intervention is designed to appear almost identical to the TTNS intervention.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ≥ 6 episodes urgency incontinence on 3-day voiding diary
- Duration of symptoms ≥ 3 months
- Off antimuscarinic or 3-adrenoreceptor agonist therapy for 2 weeks
- No known neurologic disease
- Ability to complete home sessions and clinic follow up
- Ability to complete voiding diaries
- Internet access and proficiency
- English or Spanish-speaking
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant
- Known or suspected urinary retention
- Symptomatic urinary tract infection unresolved at the time of randomization
- Recurrent urinary tract infection (≥ 3/12 months)
- Bladder pain syndrome
- Known or suspected advanced (stage III or IV) pelvic organ prolapse
- Neurogenic bladder
- Current or prior bladder malignancy
- Current or previous use of bladder Botox injections, percutaneous tibial nerve stimulation, or sacral neuromodulation
- Pacemaker or other implantable device
- Disease affecting lower extremities
- Bilateral metallic lower limb implant
- Incarceration

eligibility.gender_description: Trial is open to biologically female participants only as this is the target population of interest.

overall_official.affiliation: University of California San Diego/Kaiser Permanente San Diego
